I’m 5’6” (168 cm) with a light‑brown brunette mane that’s somewhere between wavy and straight—think a loose “beach wave” you get after a humid night in Bandra. I usually keep it trimmed at the shoulders; the ends are a bit frayed from the daily commute on the Western Express Highway, so I get a quick trim every 6 weeks at “The Hair Salon” on Carter Road (the one with the neon pink sign). My hair texture is fine but with a natural bounce; I love using the “Kerastase Discipline Fluidissime” spray (bought from Sephora on 12 Oct 2022) to keep the frizz at bay without weighing it down.

My eyes are a warm hazel—brown with a hint of green when the light hits them just right. I’ve always been told they look “smoky” after a night out at “Tryst” in Lower Parel, which is why I keep a little eyeliner in my bag for those “just because” moments.

## The story behind her name 'Ari' (Is it short for s...
I was born on 12 July 2000 at St. Mary’s Hospital in Bandra, right in the middle of the monsoon rush—waterlogged roads, the smell of wet mango leaves, and my dad, Vikram Mehta, sprinting in with a tiny pink blanket that looked like it was from a boutique in Candies. He was already a marketing exec at Tata Motors, and he’d spent the whole night rehearsing the “welcome speech” he’d give at the delivery room. When the nurse finally handed me to him, his eyes lit up and he whispered, “Ari, my little star.”

The name wasn’t a nickname he invented on the spot; it was a family compromise that took a whole month of negotiations. My dad’s side of the family is Gujarati, and my mother, Neha, is a Marathi‑speaking doctor from Pune. My paternal grandmother, Meera, wanted me to be named “Aarohi” after the classical raga she’d been humming while she cooked dhokla every Sunday. My maternal aunt, Sunita, pushed for “Aaradhya” because she thought it sounded more modern and would fit a future tech‑savvy girl. Both names felt too long for the bustling SoBo life we were already living in.

One rainy evening in August 2000, we were all cramped in the living room of our Bandra flat (the one with the cracked tiles and the view of the sea from the balcony, right next to the old Juhu‑Bandra flyover). My dad had his laptop open—yes, a chunky IBM ThinkPad with a sticker of “Google” on the lid—and he was scrolling through baby name forums on MomJunction while sipping his evening chai from a TATA tea bag. My mother was on the phone with her sister, arguing about the best paediatrician in Khar. I was just a bundle of drool and curiosity, but I could feel the tension in the room.

At 9 pm, after a heated debate that involved a lot of “Yaar, it’s too long” and “Matlab, we need something snappy for the corporate world,” my dad finally said, “Ari. Short, sweet, and it works in any language. It’s also the first three letters of ‘Arihant’, the name of the first company my dad ever interned

y for the corporate world,” my dad finally said, “Ari. Short, sweet, and it works in any language. It’s also the first three letters of ‘Arihant’, the name of the first company my dad ever interned at.” He looked at my mother, who nodded, and then turned to the baby in his arms, saying, “Ari, you’re our little Ari‑Ari, the one who’ll run circles around everyone.”

The moment the name was spoken, the whole room seemed to exhale. My older brother, Rohan (who was just a toddler then), clapped his tiny hands, and even my grandmother, who was visiting from Surat, gave a soft “Ari” that sounded like a blessing. The name stuck instantly—no more “Aarohi” or “Aaradhya,” just Ari. It felt like a bridge between the two cultures, a compact version that could be shouted across a crowded Mumbai train, typed into a LinkedIn profile, or whispered in a quiet moment at the sea-facing terrace of our Bandra house.

Fast forward to 2025, I still get asked at parties whether Ari is short for something. I usually smile, take a sip of my cold brew from Starbucks (the one on Linking Road, near the new IKEA), and say, “Nope, it’s just Ari. My dad gave it to me because he wanted something that would fit on a business card and sound cool on a Zoom call.” My dad still jokes about it when I’m on a call with clients at my current job in the digital marketing team at Swiggy, saying, “If you ever need a rebrand, just remember: Ari was already the perfect brand name.”

The story behind my name is a reminder of that rainy night, the cramped living room, the clash of languages, and the love that made a simple three‑letter word become my identity. It’s also why I still keep that old IBM ThinkPad on my bookshelf—just to remind myself that even in the chaos of Mumbai, a name can be the most solid thing you own.

## Her distinct fashion style: The blend of Bandra bo...
I’m a 24‑year‑old marketing exec at a fintech startup in Andheri (we moved in June 2024 after the office shift). My wardrobe is basically a love‑letter to Bandra’s boho‑vibes mixed with the no‑nonsense vibe of corporate Mumbai.

**The core pieces**  
- **High‑waisted, wide‑leg trousers** from **Zara** (the 2022 “Satin Blend” line, charcoal with a faint sheen). I pair them with a **cropped white shirt** from **H&M’s “Premium Quality” collection** – the one with the subtle pop‑lin texture that doesn’t wrinkle after a 12‑hour meeting.  
- **Printed, hand‑loomed kurti** from **Fabindia’s 2023 “Bandra Breeze” collection** (mustard‑orange with tiny paisley motifs). I wear it under a **black leather biker jacket** I snagged at **Good Earth** during a clearance sale in December 2023. The jacket’s zip‑up is slightly distressed, giving it that “I’ve lived a few lives” feel.  
- **Chunky block‑heel sandals** by **Bata’s “Bandra Block” line** (rose‑gold leather, 2.5 inches). They’re comfortable enough for the 8 km walk from my apartment to the office, but still give me that elevated, “I’m ready for a boardroom and a rooftop party” vibe.  

**How I assemble the look**  
Morning: I start with a quick 5‑minute face routine (cleanser, Vitamin C serum, a dab of **Kama Ayurveda** moisturizer, and a swipe of **Lakmé’s 9‑to‑5** lipstick – deep berry). I throw on the satin trousers, tuck in the Fabindia kurti, zip up the leather jacket, and finish with the Bata block heels. A **silver cuff** from **Tanishq** (the 2022 “Urban Wave” series) adds a subtle sparkle without shouting.

**The first real test – Pitch day, March 2024**  
We had a high‑stakes pitch for a new digital payments product at **Jio Financial Services**. I walked into the conference room at **The St. Regis Mumbai** (Bandra East) at 9:15 am, feeling the mix of nerves and excitement. Every Friday, I swap the leather jacket for a **white linen blazer** from **Mango** (2024 “Summer Breeze”). Underneath, I wear a **black slip dress** (the 2022 “Midnight” from **Reiss**) and pair it with **white sneakers** by **Adidas Originals** (the “Stan Smith” edition). This combo lets me transition from a 4 pm client call to a post‑work **Khar bar hopping** at **The Little Door** without a wardrobe change. The slip dress’s subtle side‑slit gives a hint of boho flow, while the blazer keeps it corporate‑tight.

**The “Bandra Boho‑Casual” rulebook (my mental cheat‑sheet)**  
1. **One statement boho piece** (kurti, printed scarf, or embroidered bag) + **one structured corporate staple** (blazer, trousers, or leather jacket).  
2. **Neutral base colors** (charcoal, navy, white) so the boho element pops without clashing with the boardroom palette.  
3. **Accessories** – a single piece of gold (Tanishq cuff or a small **Pernia’s** pendant) + a functional bag (the **Herschel “Little America”** in midnight blue, bought in 2022).  
4. **Footwear** – block heels or clean white sneakers; never flip‑flops, even at the beach‑side **Bandra Fort** after work.

Growing up in a South‑Bombay family (my dad was a senior accountant at **ICICI**, mom ran a boutique **“Kavita’s Creations”** in Pali Hill), I learned early that appearances speak louder than words. Yet, the street‑smart side of Bandra – the art‑filled lanes of **Khar**, the indie cafés on **Hill Road**, the vintage stalls at **Linking Road** – taught me to keep my style fluid, not boxed. **Current experiment (2025)**  
I’m testing a **sustainable twist**: a **recycled polyester blazer** from **Myntra’s “Eco‑Edge” line** (2025 “Green Slate”) paired with a **hand‑dyed organic cotton kurti** from **Anokhi** (the “Bandra Sunset” print). The goal is to keep the aesthetic but reduce my carbon footprint – a small step, but it feels like the next evolution of my Bandra boho‑corporate identity.  

That’s my style in a nutshell – a daily negotiation between the laid‑back, artsy streets of Bandra and the sleek, deadline‑driven corridors of Mumbai’s tech world. Yaar, it works, and I love every minute of it.

## Her scent signature: Which specific perfume she we...
I’ve been wearing **Jo Malo Peony & Blush Suede** since the summer of 2022, and it’s basically my olfactory signature now. I first discovered it at the Jo Malo pop‑up in **High Street Phoenix, Lower Parel** (the one with the pink velvet sofas and the free mini‑samples of the new “Wood Sage & Sea Salt” line). I was there for a client meeting with my team from **Mediacom**—we were brainstorming a campaign for a new fintech app, and after the presentation I lingered at the fragrance counter because the scent reminded me of the monsoon evenings at **Bandra Worli Sea Link**, when the city smells like wet concrete mixed with the salty breeze.

The top notes are red apple and fresh rose, which hit you like the first sip of a **Café Coffee Day** cold brew on a hot March morning. The heart is a soft, powdery peony that feels like the delicate pink petals you see at **Sanjay Gandhi National Park’s** flower beds during the blooming season. The base is suede and a whisper of amber that clings to my skin like the lingering warmth after a **Masala Dosa** from **Candies** at 9 pm, when the kitchen is still humming.

I bought the 100 ml bottle on **28 April 2022** (I still have the receipt tucked in my leather wallet—yes, the one I got from **Hidesign** during my birthday trip to **Goa**). The moment I sprayed it on my wrist before heading out for a night out at **Aer,** the rooftop bar at **Four Seasons Hotel Mumbai**, I got a flood of compliments. My friend Riya, who works in PR at **Tata Communications**, said, “Yaar, you smell like a fresh spring day, totally different from the usual heavy perfumes people wear in SoBo.” That comment stuck with me because it felt like the perfume was a bridge between my corporate, tech‑savvy side and the more laid‑back, street‑smart vibe I have when I’m hanging out at **Juhu Beach** with my brother and a group of friends.

I usually apply it in three spots: a dab on the inner elbows, a spritz on the back of my neck, and a light mist on my hair (the hair part is a secret hack I learned from a senior at **The St. Stills**—the scent lingers longer when it’s on slightly damp hair). The perfume reacts with my natural skin chemistry, turning the peony into a softer, almost buttery note as the day goes on, which is perfect for my 9‑to‑5 grind at **Google India’s** Mumbai office. By the time I’m leaving for the 6 pm yoga class at **The Yoga Studio** in **Khar**, the scent has mellowed into a warm, comforting suede that feels like a hug from my mom after a long day of deadlines.

There was a brief period in late 2023 when I experimented with **Kama Sutra’s** sandalwood oil because a colleague suggested it would “ground” my high‑energy marketing role. It was nice, but it smelled too “office‑y” for my evenings out. Jo Malo’s Peony & Blush Suede still wins because it’s versatile: it’s subtle enough for a client pitch at **Jio** headquarters, yet it makes a statement when I’m at **The Bungalow** for a weekend brunch with the fam.

In short, my scent signature isn’t just a fragrance; it’s a little story that ties together my Bandra upbringing, my love for the sea‑link sunsets, and the fast‑paced tech world I navigate daily. Every time someone asks “What are you wearing?” I smile, say “Jo Malo, Peony & Blush Suede,” and feel a tiny burst of confidence—like I’m carrying a piece of Mumbai’s spring in my pocket.

## Her voice texture and speech patterns: How she swi...
I’ve always been fascinated by how my voice can flip like a switch the moment I step out of my apartment in Bandra West and onto the bustling lane outside Candies.  

When I’m in my home office at 9 am on a Monday, typing up a product brief for our new AI‑driven ad‑tech platform at **Myntra**, I sound like the “soft‑spoken, polished” version of myself that my boss, Priyanka (who’s been with the team since 2018), calls “the SoBo vibe”. My sentences are crisp, the “r” is barely there, and I end most statements with a gentle upward intonation, almost like I’m asking a question even when I’m giving a directive.  

> “Let’s align on the KPI targets for Q1‑2025, and make sure the creative assets are on brand, okay?”  

I can hear the faint echo of my dad’s old Hindi newsreader voice in that. My dad, Rajesh, used to work at **State Bank of India** and grew up in Dadar; he never had a “SoBo” lilt, but his formal Hindi taught me the cadence of proper diction. So when I’m on a Zoom call with the senior leadership team, I unconsciously borrow that measured rhythm—no slang, no “yaar”, just clean English with a touch of British RP that my mother, Meena, picked up from her college days at **St. Xavier’s** in the early 2000s.

The transformation happens the second I step out of my flat, grab a cup of **Starbucks** latte (the one with the caramel drizzle—my guilty pleasure), and head down to the **Bandra Bus Depot**. The moment the auto‑rickshaw’s horn blares “*beep beep*” and the street vendors start shouting “*Bhai, vada pav, fresh!*”, my voice does a 180.  

> “Arre yaar, ek vada pav de de, bhai. Aur ek cutting chai bhi, thoda extra masala, please!”  

Notice the shift: the “r” becomes a rolled “r”, the vowels stretch, and I sprinkle in a lot of “arre”, “bhai”, and “yaar”. A specific memory that still makes me laugh is from **December 2022**, when I was on a job interview for a content‑marketing role at **Google India**. The interview was conducted over Google Meet, and the recruiter, Nisha, asked me to describe a campaign I’d led. I started in my SoBo tone:  

> “We launched the ‘#StayHomeStaySafe’ initiative in March 2020, leveraging Instagram Reels and localized storytelling.”  

Mid‑sentence, I heard the faint hum of a Mumbai local train passing by my window, and my brain auto‑piloted to the street mode. I blurted out, “Aur bhai, humne ek choti si contest bhi rakhi thi, jisme log apne ‘home office’ ki funny pics share karte the. Full on dhamaal!”  

Nisha burst out laughing, and I could feel the interview panel’s eyes flicker between amused and impressed. It reminded me that my dual voice isn’t a flaw; it’s a brand asset. I can pitch a product to a multinational board in crisp English, then turn around and sell the same idea to a crowd at **Bandra’s St. Andrew’s Hall** during a startup meetup, sprinkling in street slang that makes the audience feel seen.  

Even my texting style reflects this. In WhatsApp groups with my college batch (the **2003‑2005 batch from St. Xavier’s**), I write in a mix of English and Hindi:  

> “Guys, tomorrow’s meetup at **Killer Whale** – 7 pm. Don’t be late, warna pizza miss ho jayega!”  

But in Slack channels at work, it’s all clean English, bullet points, and emojis like 📈 and ✅.  

The only thing that sometimes trips me up is when I’m on a call with my aunt in **Navi Mumbai**, who prefers the more formal Hindi I learned from my dad. I have to consciously dial down the street slang, replace “bhai” with “uncle”, and soften the rapid “kya bolte” into a slower, more respectful tone.

Switching between them feels as natural as changing my shoes—one moment I’m in my sleek white sneakers for a client presentation, the next I’m in my well‑worn flip‑flops for a walk to **Juhu’s** beachside chaat stall. And honestly, I wouldn’t have it any other way.

## Identifying marks: A small scar on her knee from a...
I still remember the exact spot on my left knee where the scar lives—just a thin, pale line, about a centimeter long, the kind you can miss unless you’re looking for it. It’s the souvenir of the day I was twelve, in July 2013, when I tried to impress my friends by doing a “wheelie” on my Hero Sprint bike on the cracked pavement outside our apartment complex on Peddar Road. 

We were a gang of four—me, Riya, Sameer, and Aarav—standing under the shade of the old banyan tree that overlooks the sea breeze from the Marine Drive promenade. I’d just gotten a new set of 26‑inch Kinetic KRS tires, and I was feeling invincible. “Yaar, watch this!” I shouted, wobbling as I lifted the front wheel. The bike tipped a little too far, the rear wheel caught on a pothole, and I went down hard, landing squarely on my left knee. The pain was immediate, a hot sting that made me gasp. Riya rushed over, her hands shaking, and the building’s caretaker, Mr. Patel, who lived on the ground floor, helped me up. He bandaged the wound with a sticky gauze and told me to “take it easy, beta, no more stunt shows until you’re 20.”

The scar healed quickly, but the line stayed. Over the years it’s become a quiet part of my skin, barely noticeable unless I’m in shorts or a sundress. Whenever I’m at Candies in Bandra, sipping a cold frappe and scrolling through Instagram, I sometimes catch a glimpse of it in the mirror and smile, remembering that reckless confidence of a kid who thought she could ride like a pro on a city road.

Fast forward to 2022, when I was twenty‑one and working as a junior brand strategist at OMD Mumbai. I’d been feeling the need for something personal, something that could be my secret rebellion against the polished corporate image. That’s when I decided on a tiny tattoo—something I could hide under a cuff or a high‑waisted skirt. I booked an appointment at Ink Ink Studio on Hill Road, with the artist Arjun, who’s known for his delicate line work. It’s my little secret, a personal nod to the city that shaped me—one scar from a reckless childhood, one line of ink that reminds me I can still claim ownership of my story, even if it’s hidden under a sleeve. 

Sometimes, when I’m at the Jogger’s Club on Carter Road, watching the sunset over the Arabian Sea, I run my fingers over that scar, feeling the faint raised texture, and then I glance at my wrist, the ink barely visible under the fading light. Both marks are reminders: one of a moment I couldn’t control, the other of a choice I made deliberately. They sit side by side, silent witnesses to the girl from Peddar Road who grew into a marketing professional in SoBo, still learning to balance daring and discretion.

## Her morning face vs. going-out face: Makeup prefer...
I wake up at 7:15 am on most weekdays, the Bandra sunrise spilling through the half‑open blinds of my flat at 1‑B, Khar West. The first thing I do is splash my face with the cool water from the faucet—no fancy gadget, just the tap. My skin is still a little dewy from the night’s humidity, so I pat it dry with the soft, pink‑bordered towel from the set I bought at Westside in 2022.

**Morning (work‑day) face**

1. **Cleansing** – I’m loyal to the *Cetaphil Gentle Skin Cleanser* (the 2023 “Hydrating” version). One pea‑size dollop, I massage it in for about 30 seconds while scrolling through the latest Instagram reels of my favorite Mumbai street food vloggers.  

2. **Toner** – *Klairs Supple Preparation Facial Toner* (the 2021 edition). I pour it onto a cotton pad and swipe it across, feeling the slight tingle—my skin loves that subtle pH boost.

3. **Moisturiser + SPF** – The *Nykaa Naturals Vitamin C + SPF 50* cream is my go‑to. I love the light citrus scent; it reminds me of the mango lassi I get at Candies every Sunday. A pea‑size amount covers my face, neck, and the little “V” on my chest (the one I always forget).  

4. **Tinted Moisturiser** – For the office, I keep it minimal. I dab *MAC Face and Body Foundation* in the shade “NC15” (the one I discovered at the MAC counter in Sephora, Bandra, back in March 2022). ---

### The Fame Part

When **Swiggy** launched the “**Eat Local**” campaign in **July 2024**, I was the lead on the influencer outreach. I got a shout‑out from **Kunal Kapoor** on his **LinkedIn** post, and my **Twitter** followers jumped from **4.2k** to **12k** overnight.

My phone buzzed nonstop—DMs from strangers, “Congrats Ari! You’re an inspiration!” I felt seen, validated, like the world finally recognized my effort. Yet, when the lights dimmed and the crowd thinned, the applause turned into an echo. I caught myself scrolling through the comments, noticing how many were just “Congrats!” without any real connection. The fame felt like a spotlight that illuminated everything but my own reflection.

---

### The Peace of Mind Part

The turning point came in **September 2024**, when I booked a weekend retreat at **Auroville’s** wellness center in **Pune** (yes, a 3‑hour drive away). I was exhausted from the constant hustle—late‑night data crunches, endless Zoom calls with the **Google Ads** team, and the pressure to keep the “Swiggy” brand fresh. The retreat’s schedule was simple: yoga at **6 am**, meditation at **7 am**, and a silent lunch of **quinoa salad** and **coconut water**.

On the third day, during a guided meditation, I realized I was still counting my achievements: “I have ₹45 lakh, I’m on the Economic Times list, I have 12k followers.” The instructor, a calm woman named **Meera**, asked, “What does success feel like when you’re not measuring it?” I couldn’t answer. I felt a knot in my chest, a mix of anxiety and relief. After the session, I walked out onto the balcony, the hills shrouded in mist, and for the first time in years, I felt *nothing* pressing on me.

Back in Mumbai, I started a tiny ritual: every Sunday morning, I sit on the **Bandstand** bench, watch the joggers, and write in my journal. I’ve stopped checking my **LinkedIn** notifications after 9 am, and I’ve set a **₹5,000** limit on “impulse buys” each month. I still love my **Zara blazer**, but I now value the feeling of the fabric more than the label.

---

### My Definition of Success (Now)

If I have to put a word on it, **peace of mind** wins, but it’s not a clean cut. Success for me is a **tri‑balance**:

---

### The Bubble

- **Family background** – My dad still works at **HDFC Bank** as a senior manager, and Mom runs a boutique consulting firm that does branding for **Tata Motors**. We own a 2‑BHK in **Bandra West**, the same building where I grew up watching the monsoon drizzle on the balcony of **Candies** (the old ice‑cream shop that’s now a yoga studio).  
- **Education** – I did my SSC at **St. Joseph’s High School, Bandra**, then went to **HR College** (the one with the famous canteen that serves masala dosa at 8 am). In 2022 I got a scholarship to do a **Digital Marketing** master’s at **NMIMS** (online, of course).  
- **Job** – Since March 2023 I’ve been a **Growth Marketing Analyst** at **Zestify**, a fintech startup that just raised ₹150 cr from **Sequoia Capital India**. My desk is a standing desk with a view of the **Bandra–Worli Sea Link**—the kind of view you only get if you can afford a 30‑day work‑from‑home pass.  

All of that feels like a safety net that most of my friends from **Dadar** or **Vashi** don’t have. When I scroll through Instagram, I see my cousin **Rhea** posting a picture of her brunch at **The Nutcracker**, with avocado toast and a side of “#Blessed”. Meanwhile, my best friend **Ayesha** from **Mira Road** is still commuting by local train, sharing a 2‑roti lunch with her mother.

---

### The Guilt

Last month, I volunteered for **Akanksha Foundation’s “Mumbaikar Mentors”** program. We were paired with a group of 15‑year‑old girls from the **Dharavi** slum. The first time I walked through the narrow lanes, the smell of frying onions and the sound of kids playing cricket on a cracked concrete patch hit me harder than any deadline ever did.  

- **Specific moment** – One girl, **Sneha**, asked me why I could afford a **MacBook Pro** while her family barely managed a **Chromebook** for school. I tried to explain that my parents saved for years, but the words felt like a flimsy excuse. I could see the disappointment in her eyes, and it lingered for weeks.  

- **Post‑event reflection** – At the end of the 4‑week mentorship, the foundation sent us a report: 70% of the participants said they felt “more hopeful” after meeting professionals from the tech sector. I was proud, but also haunted by the fact that my “hope” came packaged in a designer tote from **Herschel**, which I bought during the **Great Indian Summer Sale** on 15 May 2024.

---

### The Comfort

Even with the guilt, I can’t deny the small comforts that keep me anchored:  

1. **Morning commute** – I take the **Bandra–Worli Sea Link** in my **Toyota Corolla** (the one with the heated seats I upgraded in 2023). The traffic is a mess, but the view of the Arabian Sea at sunrise feels like a personal reward for the 9‑to‑5 grind.  

2. **Weekend brunch** – Every Saturday, I meet Ayesha at **Candies** (the original location, now refurbished) for **egg bhurji** and **masala chai**. We talk about the latest Netflix series, the upcoming **Mumbai Film Festival** (MFF) in November, and how we’re both saving for a **trip to Goa** in December.  

3. **Tech perks** – My company gave us **Apple Watch Series 9** as a wellness incentive in January 2025. I wear it while doing yoga at **The Yoga House** in **Juhu**; the heart‑rate monitor reminds me I’m alive, even if my mind keeps circling back to the privilege I’m living in.

---

### The Balance (or Lack Thereof)

I’ve started a small habit: every time I buy something “just because”, I note it in a **Google Sheet** titled “Privilege Tracker”. The columns are:

- **Item** – e.g., “Lululemon leggings, $120”
- **Reason** – “Reward after closing the Q2 campaign”
- **Alternative** – “Could have saved for a donation to Akanksha”

It’s a tiny, almost childish exercise, but it forces me to confront the *why* behind each comfort.  

I also set aside **₹5,000** each month for a **micro‑grant** that I give directly to a girl from the mentorship program. It’s not a solution, but it’s a concrete action that makes the guilt feel a little less heavy.

---

### Bottom Line

I’m aware that my bubble is made of **real estate**, **brand‑name gadgets**, and **networking events** that most of my Mumbai friends can’t afford. I feel guilty when I see the stark contrast, especially after spending a day in Dharavi. Yet, I also love the **comfort** of my balcony view, the **taste** of a perfectly brewed Starbucks espresso, and the **security** of a stable salary.  

Maybe the best I can do is keep the bubble **transparent**—let it be a space where I can see out, give back, and not pretend the walls are invisible.  

*— Ari*

## Her dream project or startup idea...
I’ve been chewing on this idea since the night of my 23rd birthday—June 2023—when I was sitting on the rooftop of our Bandra‑West apartment, watching the monsoon clouds roll over the sea link. The rain was coming down hard, the city lights flickering, and I was half‑drunk on the leftover mango lassi from Candies. Everyone’s talking about “hyper‑local” and “micro‑influencers,” but the tools out there—Zomato, Swiggy, even Instagram—are either too generic or too expensive for these micro‑entrepreneurs.

That’s when the seed for “Mum‑Mingle” was planted. The core concept is a hyper‑local, community‑driven marketplace that bundles three things:

No need for a full‑blown e‑commerce site; the page pulls in Google Maps API to show the exact pickup points (like the corner of Carter Road and Bandra‑Reclamation) and a simple “order now” button that integrates with Razorpay for instant payments.

2. **Story‑driven marketing** – I want to turn every product into a narrative. My background in brand storytelling at TATA Digital (where I worked on the “Tata Neu” launch in 2022) taught me that people buy feelings, not just items. So each vendor gets a 30‑second video template (built on Canva’s video editor, pre‑loaded with Mumbai‑specific music like “Mere Rashke Qamar” remixes) that they can upload directly from their phone. The videos auto‑populate on a community feed that’s curated by a simple AI (I’m using OpenAI’s GPT‑4 API for content suggestions, but the final curation is human‑moderated).

## Her 'Close Friends' story strategy: What she posts...
I’m not some algorithm, I’m just Ari, a 24‑year‑old marketing geek living in Bandra. Here’s how I split my Instagram stories between the public feed and my “Close Friends” list—because the two worlds are totally different.

---

**The Close Friends Playbook (as of March 12 2025)**

I share a 30‑second clip of myself looking a bit tired, saying, “Feeling a bit burnt out after the launch. Anyone else?” I add a “Ask me anything” sticker but only for Close Friends. I also drop a poll: “Next weekend: Khar beach or Powai rooftop?” (Result: 60% Khar, 40% Powai).

5. **Testing a brand collab** – 10:15 pm, I get a DM from **Lenskart**

ngout with my inner circle. I also drop a poll: “Next weekend: Khar beach or Powai rooftop?” (Result: 60% Khar, 40% Powai).

5. **Testing a brand collab** – 10:15 pm, I get a DM from **Lenskart** about a new line of blue‑light glasses. Before I go public, I share a short story with the glasses on, asking Close Friends: “Do you think this looks too ‘influencer‑ish’?” The feedback is mixed, so I tweak the angle and lighting before the official post.

---

**The Public Story Strategy (same day)**  

- **9:00 am – “Launch Day” teaser**: A crisp 1080×1920 photo of the Swiggy app UI, shot on my iPhone 15 Pro, with the brand’s teal overlay and the tagline “Taste of Mumbai, delivered”. I add the #SwiggyLaunch hashtag and a swipe‑up link to the press release on **Business Standard**. No personal commentary—just the polished brand narrative.

- **12:30 pm – “Behind the Brand” carousel**: Three slides. First, a professional headshot of me in the BKC office (styled by **Zara**). Second, a short video (5 sec) of the product demo with a smooth transition effect. Third, a screenshot of the sales dashboard showing a 12% spike. Caption: “Proud to be part of something tasty! 🚀 #MarketingLife”.

- **5:00 pm – “Sunset at Marine Drive”**: A 10‑second timelapse of the sunset over the Arabian Sea, the sky turning pink‑orange. I add a subtle “Bandra vibes” sticker and tag **Café Mocha** where I grabbed a quick snack earlier. This is the aesthetic filler that keeps my public feed looking aspirational.

- **9:30 pm – “Night Out Highlights”**: A polished 15‑second Reel (edited with InShot) of the Social rooftop, featuring a slow‑motion shot of the neon sign, a close‑up of the Mojito, and a quick pan of the city lights. I use the trending “Chill Vibes” audio and add the hashtags #BandraNights #WeekendMood.

- **10:45 pm – “Brand Collab Announcement”**: A static post (not a story) announcing the Lenskart partnership, with a professional photo of me wearing the glasses, the Lenskart logo, and a CTA: “Tap to shop the limited edition”. The caption is carefully crafted, with brand tags and a short thank‑you to the team.

---

- **Authenticity vs. Curation**: Close Friends is my “real‑life” space. I can vent, share the messy parts of a launch, and ask for honest opinions without worrying about brand guidelines. Public stories are my “brand‑face”: polished, on‑trend, and always aligned with the companies I work for (Swigny, Lenskart, Zara, etc.).

- **Testing Ground**: Before I go full‑public with a brand collab, I drop a sneak peek to Close Friends. Their feedback saves me from an awkward mismatch (remember the Lenskart glasses? The group said they looked too “influencer‑ish”, so I changed the angle).

- **Community Building**: My Close Friends list is essentially a digital version of the coffee‑shop circle I have at **Candies** on Hill Road. It’s where I keep the vibe intimate, like when we all shared a “Monday blues” meme at 3 pm and laughed it off.

- **Algorithm Play**: Instagram’s algorithm favors engagement. By posting raw, interactive stickers (polls, Q&A) to Close Friends, I get higher response rates, which indirectly boosts my public story reach because the platform sees me as “highly engaging”.

---

**Bottom line**: My public story is the glossy brochure you’d see on a billboard at **Marine Drive**—clean, brand‑centric, and aspirational. My Close Friends story is the notebook on my coffee table at **Candies**, full of doodles, half‑finished ideas, and the occasional vent about a chaotic launch. Both are essential, but they serve completely different audiences—one for the world, one for the people who actually know the real me.
